description:
The latest release in the Nvidia RTX 50-series Blackwell offers the best balance of price vs performance, but to be clear - pre-launch hype should be tempered. It's doesn't deliver RTX 4090 performance - think of it more as a price-cut RTX 4070 Super with DLSS 4 multi frame-gen support. 

See all of our benchmark data here: https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2025-nvidia-geforce-rtx-5070-review

Note: 4x MFG latency with DLSS 4 in Alan Wake 2 is 146ms, so considerably higher than the VO says. The graphs on-screen, however, are accurate. Apologies for the error and any confusion - a corrected version of this segment is here: https://youtu.be/_nuC_mWSSVs

Join the DF Supporter Program for pristine video downloads, behind the scenes content, early access to new videos, early access to DF Direct Weekly and much, much more: https://bit.ly/3jEGjvx

Subscribe for more Digital Foundry: http://bit.ly/DFSubscribe

comments.text:
Comparing FIVE different generations (for comparing longevity of what many might buy, not apples to apples)
GTX1080Ti (11GB) - still holds up reasonably well in many modern titles. No RT/DLSS 
RTX2080 (8GB) - VRAM buffer a problem, can do RT but pointless to try really
RTX3080 (10GB) - 10GB borderline for modern titles. No Frame Gen.
RTX4070 (12GB) - 12GB mostly okay currently. 2x Frame Gen can work okay at times. Much more power efficient vs previous gen.
RTX5070 (12GB) - price/value? Utility of 3x/4x Frame Gen? No GPU PhysX in most titles? WTF?
*Seems to me as a previous GTX1080 (non-Ti) owner that a GTX1080Ti is still a pretty good card to hold on to for many people. Whereas an RTX2080 8GB would be an arguably crappy card. I'm glad I got the RTX4070 and do intend to get a LONG time out of it.
If I'd had the GTX1080Ti I'd probably still be using it AND a 1440p monitor and maybe not gone 4K. Since I wanted a 4K gaming monitor the RTX4070 seemed like a good choice (what with upscaling making raw raster vs resolution less of an issue)
comments.author: @photonboy999

comments.text:
3x and 4x Frame Gen utility?
I'm struggling to understand many uses for more than 2x Frame Gen. With every "fake" frame you add (i.e. 3x vs 2x) the visual fidelity is reduced (in general AND especially in motion) AND the latency is increased (though NVidia can make 3x and 4x's added latency minimal). With "Oblivion Remastered" I can make 2x Frame Gen work pretty well. The main reason I use it is to reduce the MONITOR persistance blur issues as I'm trying to get to at least 80FPS...
Now if you had a 144Hz monitor your goal is a maximum of 138FPS. So with "3x" Frame Gen your "real" frames would be no more than 46FPS... that can work well, but since Frame Gen has a processing cost you should be able to get more than 2/3rds the FPS using 2x Frame Gen.
So let's assume you barely maintain an average of 132FPS with x3 Frame Gen. (plus the worst added visual artifacts)
With 2x Frame Gen you might get around 100FPS. (plus some annoying visual artifacts)
With no Frame Gen you might get around 60FPS. (no added artifacts from Frame Gen as it's off)
What's OPTIMAL in this situation for a slower-paced Game like Oblivion Remastered? Well, for me as it turns out... 100FPS with 2x Frame Gen. 132FPS with 3x looks a bit worse AND has slightly worse latency. While 100FPS (2x FG) to me feels pretty smooth.
(I wouldn't use Frame Gen below a "real" FPS of around 40FPS... so 80FPS with 2x Frame Gen... and CONVERSELY, as you get HIGHER the monitor persistance blur type issues start to go away. 100FPS to me looks pretty great. So I'm less inclined to use Frame Gen as the NEGATIVES outweight the POSITIVES. As the processing cost reduces AND the visual fidelity increases this will change but as it stands right now I don't see many use cases for more than 2x Frame Gen that I, personally, would use.)

comments.text:
Why the RTX 50 Series Is the Most Disappointing NVIDIA GPU Generation Ever
NVIDIA
Summary
RTX 50 graphics cards offer a disappointing gaming performance uplift over their RTX 40 counterparts while being hard to find in stock and costing hundreds of dollars over MSRP.
Mid-range and budget RTX 50 GPUs feature 12GB and 8GB memory buffers, respectively, which is unacceptable in 2025.
Some RTX 5090, RTX 5080, and RTX 5070 Ti cards are defective, while RTX 5090 and RTX 5080 cards also suffer from power connector issues that can result in melted power cables.

comments.author: @DarkP1

comments.text: Depends on the input frame rate. Say we have 30fps, that's around 33 milliseconds per frame (1000/30). The GPU needs to see the current and last frame to make "fake frames" - The last frame in this case is 33 milliseconds old in the very best case. Then we add the rate of generated frames, say we are generating at 120fps.. so we add the latency for that also, so that would be around 8ms... which would give use around 33+8 (=41) msecs latency for 30->120fps frame generation.
